On the side of Lingshan Creek, he raised a white ape. Sometimes it would suddenly cross the mountain and creek, and not return for a long time.
Then Yi would suck and stretch his throat, calling out in Sanskrit, and the ape would come.
At that time, people called it the White Ape's Sanskrit Call.
Master Yi was like the father of the ape, like an old ape.
After that, a group of wild apes gathered on the side of the creek.

Every time the assembly of monks finished their meal, they would collect the leftover food and send it to the ape's platform. Later, they had the mountain boys call out three or two times, and then the group of apes would come rushing.

When Emperor Wuzong of the Tang dynasty abolished Buddhism, this temple was destroyed and turned into a wilderness of overgrown grass. The feeding of the apes on the platform was all buried and forgotten.
The end of Master Yi is unknown.

The Biography of Huiying of Luoyang in the Yuanwei Dynasty, the Biography of Huiying of Luoyang in the Yuanwei Dynasty, Shi Huiying, was not known where he was from. He lived in Luoyang without any special skills, only practicing mind and precepts.
He once fell seriously ill and died, but after seven days he revived and told of the retribution and distinctions he saw in the netherworld, with no difference in the slightest detail.
Among those he saw were five monks: One was Zhi Sheng of Baoming Temple, who ascended to the heavenly palace by sitting in meditation and practicing asceticism.
Next was Dao Pin of Prajna Temple, who recited the Nirvana Sutra in forty scrolls, the same as Zhi Sheng.
Next was Tan Mo Zui of Rongjue Temple, who expounded the Nirvana Sutra and the Flower Ornament Sutra, leading a thousand disciples.
Yama King said:
Those who expound the sutras harbor self-importance and arrogance towards others, and are the most unruly among the monks.
Now I will only test those who sit in meditation and recite sutras.
Zui said:
Since I started my life, I have only enjoyed expounding the teachings and am not good at sitting in meditation or reciting sutras.ğŸ”½The king said:
Hand him over to the authorities.
There were then several blue-robed attendants who escorted him to the northwest gate, the buildings were all black, not a good place.
Next, it was Daoheng of Chanlin Temple, who chanted:
Guiding and inspiring the four kinds of donors, creating all scriptures and ten life-size statues.
The king said:
The body of a monk must concentrate the mind and guard the Way, with the intention of Chan recitation, not interfering with worldly affairs, not striving for busyness andç¹.
Although creating scriptures and images, it is just to obtain others' wealth;
Having obtained wealth, greedy thoughts arise;
Having cultivated greedy practices, the three poisons blaze, and afflictions are complete.
He entered the black gate with Zui.
Fifth was Baoming of Lingjue Temple, who claimed that before leaving the household life, he was once the governor of Longxi and created Lingjue Temple.
He then abandoned officialdom and entered the Way. Although he did not practice Chan recitation, he never missed paying respects.
The king said:
On the day you became governor, you twisted justice, abused the law, robbed the people's wealth, and falsely built this temple.
It is not your power, why bother to say this?
He was also handed over to the blue-robed ones to be sent to the black gate.
From this, Seng was enlightened.
He was the first to see the king, and the officials checked the names and records, mistakenly chasing and capturing him.

At that time, Empress Dowager Hu heard about it and sent Xu He, the Chamberlain for Ceremonials, to follow Seng's statement to scatter and investigate the temple names and the existence of the monks, and report back, saying:

To the east of the city, there is Baoming Temple; in the city, there is Prajna Temple; to the west of the city, there are three temples: Rongjue, Chanlin, and Lingjue; and Zhi Sheng, Dao Pin, Tan Mo Zui, Dao Hong, and Bao Ming, all truly exist.
The Empress Dowager praised for a long time and ordered them to sit in meditation and recite sutras, with one hundred monks always in the inner palace for offerings.
There was a subsequent edict:
It is not allowed for monks to carry scriptures and images on the streets to beg for alms, but those who privately use their own wealth to create scriptures and images can do as they please.

Zhikong entered Baiyung Mountain to live in seclusion and cultivate the Way. From then on, many monks in the capital city practiced meditation and recitation, and chanted the scriptures of the great collection.
Xi said:
Tanmozui sat and lectured on the Dharma, and because of self-importance, he entered the Black Gate.
If one who practices meditation and recitation increases self-importance, even if one knows, one cannot avoid it.
Zui argued with the Daoist Jiang Bin, and the merit of protecting the Dharma can make up for previous faults.
Do not say that all those who transmit the Dharma fall into a losing position.
The biased views of the Hu Empress have not disappeared. Alas!
Shi Yuanxiang, a monk of Fajuzisi in Chengdu Prefecture during the Tang Dynasty, was a person from Shu.
At the age of seven, he left home and was well-versed in both Chinese and foreign studies. He was good at writing and was called a prodigy.
Internally, he cultivated the precepts, and no one had any reservations about him.
In the first year of Longshuo, he fell ill and passed away in this temple.
When he was about to close his hands and feet, a long rainbow like silk flew up into the sky from his room, and the bells and ropes of the temple tower rang by themselves without wind.
The painted walls of the main gate collapsed, and every night there was the sound of drums and horns, which ceased only after more than a hundred days.
Since then, birds and sparrows did not roost in the building.
In the fourth year of Xianheng, sweet dew descended on the palm tree in front of the lecture hall.
After his death, his disciples collected his writings into more than thirty scrolls.
The stele of the stone statue in the temple, the inscription of which was written by Xiang, was probably composed together with Gong Lingkuang.

The Biography of Monk Dashi of Miaohui Temple in Yue Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Monk Dashi of Miaohui Temple in Yue Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Dashi, whose surname was Wang, was a man from Kuaiji.

From a young age, he was extraordinary and did not engage in play. He left the householder life at Miaohui Temple on Mount Gui - the temple was established in the early years of the Southern Liang dynasty.

Later, he enjoyed traveling around and met Chan Master Ren of Huangmei. He was like withered seedlings receiving rain, practicing Chan in accordance with [the master's] instructions, without any rest or slacking off.
He met Chan Master Yinzong and further polished the mirror of his mind.
In Guangzhou, he saw Vinaya Master Dao'an and further strengthened his observance of the precepts.
The four assemblies relied on him as their refuge, just as water reveres the ocean.
In the seventh year of Kaiyuan, he passed away while ill, at the age of 82.
Tang Dynasty, Jingzhao Shending's Biography, Tang Dynasty, Jingzhao Shending's Biography. Shi Shending, it is not known where he was from.
He was eccentric and upright, with hair reaching his eyebrows.
He always carried a bushel and begged in the Chang'an market.
When he got food, he would sit down and eat it.
People sometimes gave him coarse silk, cloth, brocade, gauze, and gauze, which he all sewed together and wore, without any discrimination.
Once he entered a temple and saw Dharma Master Li Zhen lecturing. He listened for a while in front of the seat and then asked Zhen, saying:
Are all things fixed?
Zhen said:
They are fixed.
Ding said:
If you say they are fixed, why do high cliffs become valleys, deep valleys become hills, those who die are reborn, and those who are born die?
All things entangle each other, and the six realms revolve. How can they be fixed?
Zhen said:
All things are not fixed.
Ding said:
If they are not fixed, why not point to heaven as earth, call earth heaven, summon stars as the moon, and order the moon as stars?
How can they be unfixed?
Zhen had no response.
At that time, the assembly was amazed by his eloquence, which flowed like a river.
Master Zhen's profound learning was defeated, and he showed some embarrassment.
Zhang Wencheng saw this and sighed, saying:
Observing the Dharma master's swift eloquence, he is indeed a bodhisattva in the stages of practice.
Ding said:
When a bodhisattva obtains something, he is not delighted; when he loses something, he is not resentful; when beaten, he is not angry; when humiliated, he does not become angry.

Now, if I were to obtain something, I would be delighted; if I were to lose something, I would be resentful; if beaten, I would be angry; if humiliated, I would become angry. From this perspective, I am far from being a bodhisattva.
At that time, the assembly was astonished and dispersed with palms joined.
The author says:
Answering others' questions, slow and clever is not as good as quick and clumsy.
Now, separated from the family for several hundred years, I suddenly offer a response.
The author says:
The valley changes and moves, life comes and death goes, myriad categories entangle each other, the five realms revolve, this is precisely the unchanging principle, can it not be definite?
The sutra says 'the characteristics of the world are always abiding,' this is it.
Moreover, it is said 'heaven, earth, stars, and moon, each according to their order, will eventually be destroyed,' can it not be indefinite?
The sutra says 'the conflagration of the kalpa burns, the great trichiliocosm is destroyed together,' this is it.
Now, without destroying worldly phenomena, he speaks of the true nature of phenomena. Can it not be neither definite nor indefinite?
Although it is both definite and indefinite, it is the characteristic of liberation, is it not?
Moreover, he says that having joy and anger is not being a bodhisattva. Although bodhisattvas have joy and anger, they are neither joy nor anger. If not a bodhisattva, then who?
Now, I will perhaps dispel the depression of Li Zhen.
The Biography of Shi Hong, a Monk from Jingzhao during the Tang Dynasty, Part 1. The Biography of Shi Hong, a Monk from Jingzhao during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Hong was a man from Qi'an.
During the Shenlong era, he came to roam in the capital city. He was aloof and held himself in high regard, rarely speaking.
When he spoke, he was bizarre and strange, quite skilled in the study of geography, divining burial sites, second only to Guo Jingchun and Yixing.
But he came and went through the gate of Duke Yun, Wei An Shi, and his relationship with Wei was close.
One day he said to him:

The poor monk saw a piece of land at Fengqiyuan, about twenty mu, with the shape of a dragon coiling and rising. If one buries here, one's descendants will surely occupy the highest positions for generations.
Wei said:
The old man has a villa to the south of the city. When I have free time, I will accompany the National Teacher to visit the land and ask about the price.
Traveling together in the forests and springs, it will also enhance our lofty joy.
On another day, Wei followed the previous agreement and was about to order his carriage. Wei Gong's wife said:
Your Lordship is a minister of the emperor, and the National Teacher is proficient in yin and yang and divination. Why would you secretly travel outside the city to seek a burial site?
This is not appropriate.
Thus, he stopped.
Wei said:
My younger brother Tao has a son who died young and has not yet been buried. I will show him this land.
Hong said:
If your younger brother obtains this land, he will not obtain the position of a high minister. He will only be a high-ranking official.
Tao bought a burial site for his deceased child, and later became the Director of the Imperial Clan and the Envoy for Ceremonial Etiquette before passing away.
Every time Hong went to inspect mountains and fields, he would draw maps of them. Once, he said to Zhang Shu from the east of Luoyang:
To the left of the missing gate, there is a good mountain ridge, which the Prime Minister can use.
Shu said:
Having reached the pinnacle of a civil official's career, what good fortune could surpass this?
Hong said:
No one can surpass this.
He then consulted Yuan, the Censor-in-Chief, saying:
My ancestor had a will.
Later, Yuan requested leave to go to Luoyang in the east, and after moving the tomb, he returned, and it had already been a year.
Hong passed by the missing gate again, and the site had already become a tomb. He asked the residents, saying:
These are the pine and cypress trees of the Yuan family.
Hong said:
The mysterious number is in accord with the Yuan family. One can just wait for its transformation.
In a few years, Yuan indeed rose to a high position.
Hong once admonished Yan Gong, saying:
Do not take soil from the northwest corner of the house.
Later, the pit was completed, with holes in three or two places. Hong was startled and said to Yan Gong:
Disaster!
It will bring misfortune to the public's wealth and nobility, and only one person will be left.
In another twenty years, disaster will befall the virtuous young man.

When Jun and Gei accepted the false official positions of Lu Shan, and Suzong recaptured the capital, they were sentenced to death for their crimes. The Supreme Emperor insisted on executing them, all in accordance with Hong's words.
During the reigns of Xuanzong and Suzong, they all revered Hong as the National Preceptor.
His predictions and divinations were never wrong.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½Biography of Shi Huirui, Dharma Master of Wanguan Temple in Luoyang of the Tang Dynasty
Shi Huirui, whose secular surname was Xin, was a person from Donglai.

During the reign of Emperor Zhongzong, he was ordained and after receiving full ordination, he met with Yijing Tripiá¹­aka Master and went to the Western Regions to seek the ultimate of the One Vehicle, always admiring it in his heart.
Huirui then vowed to travel to the Western Regions.

He first sailed on a ship across the ocean for three years, passing through various countries in the East China Sea - Kunlun, Buddha's Vow, Lion Continent, and so on - and reaching India, paying homage to the holy sites.
He searched for Sanskrit texts and sought out spiritual friends for thirteen years.
Having received their teachings, wishing to benefit others, he shook his staff and returned home, traveling alone and far.
In the snowy mountains and barbarian lands, he traveled for another four years.
Having experienced much hardship, deeply despising the world, he wondered in which country or land there was happiness and no suffering.
What Dharma and what practice could quickly lead one to see the Buddha?
He asked all the Tripiá¹­aka masters in India, and they all praised the Pure Land. He also consulted with them;
As for speed, it is the road for one lifetime;
At the end of this life, one will definitely be reborn in the Land of Ultimate Bliss, and personally be able to serve and attend upon AmitÃ¢bha Buddha.
Having heard it, he accepted it on his head and gradually reached the country of GandhÄra in northern India.
To the northeast of the royal city, there was a large mountain, and on the mountain there was an image of AvalokiteÅ›vara. Those with sincere wishes and prayers often saw the deity's manifestation.

Sun then knocked his head on the ground for seven days, and also fasted, vowing to end his life. On the seventh night, just before midnight, AvalokiteÅ›vara manifested in the sky with a purple-golden body, over ten feet tall, sitting on a jeweled lotus, extending his right hand to pat Sun on the head, saying:

You wish to transmit the Dharma, benefiting yourself and others. In the Western Pure Land, the Buddha Land of AmitÄbha, encourage people to recite the Buddha's name and sÅ«tras, vowing to be reborn there. Once you reach that land, you will see the Buddha and me, and attain great benefits.
You should know that the Pure Land Dharma gate surpasses all practices.
Having said this, [AvalokiteÅ›vara] suddenly disappeared.
Sun, having fasted and being exhausted, heard this and became strong again.
When he returned to the east of the mountain range, he traveled through more than seventy countries in total, for eighteen years, and in the seventh year of Kaiyuan, he finally reached Chang'an.
He presented the Buddha's true appearance and Sanskrit scriptures, which enlightened the emperor's mind, and he was given the title Tripiá¹­aka Master of Compassion and Pity.
Sheng always diligently practiced the Pure Land teachings and wrote the Collection on Rebirth in the Pure Land, which is circulated in the world.
His teachings were the same as those of Shandao and Shaokang, who were teaching at the same time.
Also, many monks were confused about the five pungent vegetables, hingu.
Hingu is often explained differently by people, some say it is a kind of cabbage or coriander, some say it is realgar, only in the Collection on the Pure Land, a separate text is given, which says:
The five pungent vegetables, in this land there are only four, one is garlic, two is scallion, three is onion, four is leek, lacking hingu.
The Sanskrit is slightly corrupted, the correct pronunciation is hingu, it is not seen in other countries.
When he returned to Khotan, he finally got to see it.
The root is as thick as a small turnip root and is white, with a smell like garlic. The people of that country plant it to take the root and eat it.
At that time, it was winter when he arrived there, and he did not see any branches or leaves.
Leeks and coriander are not the five pungent vegetables, so there is no sin in eating them.
Is it a verification seen by the sun itself?
In the seventh year of Tianbao, he died at the temple where he resided, at the age of sixty-nine.
He was buried at Bai Luyuan, and a small pagoda was built.
Shi Zhen, a monk of Xiuguang Temple in Yuzhang, was a man from Jinhua and had the surname Wang.
When Zhen was a child, he left home and awakened to the Way as a young boy. He developed great diligence and upheld the precepts firmly.
In one family, several people wore monastic robes.
Zhen studied under ancient masters, and his understanding surpassed that of the sages;
the principles of the eight divisions of scriptures were as if in the palm of his hand;
the source of the three vehicles' teachings was exhausted within his understanding.
In the sixth year of Tianbao, the prefect Qin and the recorder Di knew of his lofty conduct and thus recommended him, and he became the abbot of Xiuguo Temple.
The two officials often said to each other:
Master Zhen is proficient in the profound and wondrous Dharma, and the supreme truth. Ask one and get three.
His words resonate like an echo.
In the past, Lishe was eloquent, and Seng Hui was knowledgeable, they were his equals, not to be mentioned on the same day.

He passed away in the temple in the eighth year, and the magistrate of the county, Wang Zhi, wrote an inscription to praise his virtue, and Hong Yuandeng wrote it down.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½Biography of Shen Kou of Dayu Temple in Yue Prefecture, Tang Dynasty
Shi Shen Kou, whose place of origin is unknown.
He entered the Dharma stream at a young age and took self-discipline as his duty. His conduct was lofty and strict, not harsh but austere.

In his later years, he admired Vinaya Master Dayi of Chengxin Temple. He studied the Three Contemplations together with the Tiantai School and attained the principle from Chan Master Zixi, which was during the Baoying years.

Moreover, his words and writing were grand and expansive, with ornate and colorful expressions. His Praise for the True Image of Master Lang and Preface to the Textual Explanation of the Lotus Sutra were unparalleled at the time and were treasured by the world.
It is not known how he ended.

Tang Dynasty, Jingzhao Prefecture, Zhen Guo Temple, Pure Giving Biography, Tang Dynasty, Jingzhao Prefecture, Zhen Guo Temple, Pure Giving Biography, Shi Pure Giving was originally from the Western Regions, and his Sanskrit name was untranslatable in Chinese.
He traveled to the capital and was revered by the people.
During the Shang Yuan period, he said he was crossing the east. People saw him with the appearance of a young child, and he said he was already 600 years old.
Some said he was 80 years old.
His speech and demeanor were vigorous, and his movements were not weak.
Emperor Dezong heard of this and ordered him to enter the palace. The imperial treatment was extremely generous, and he was asked to seek the way of longevity.
Pure Giving said:
The mind and spirit like stillness, but now they are disturbed by the dust and realms. How can one attain profound tranquility?
If one wants to prolong life without seclusion and tranquility, it is like climbing a tree to pick lotus flowers - how can it be possible?
Your Majesty wants to prolong life, which comes from simplicity and tranquility of the spirit.
When the spirit is tranquil, longevity is attained; when desires are few, the body is at ease.
As for the methods, I do not know about them.
The Emperor thus deeply respected him.
In the third year of Yongtai, he knew he would surely pass away, and sent his disciple to present his robe and alms bowl. The Emperor bestowed purple robes on the disciple.

had profound insight and far-reaching understanding, and upheld his will with constancy. He had a profound understanding of the true teaching, and did not rely on heretical methods.
In the end, he transmitted the teaching of Sui Dynasty Zhizhe, and had a profound understanding of the profound principles.
The gate of Jingxi was far difficult to glimpse and hope for.
During the Dali period, Master Zhanran entrusted the Notes on the Auxiliary Practice of the Mohe Zhiguan, which could be used to spread the teaching, like a divine horse that can travel far.
At that time, Yuan Hao of the same gate was far-sighted and knowledgeable, and could not compete with him.
In the twenty-first year of the Zhenyuan period, the Japanese monk SaichÅ, also a monk from the barbarian land of the East, was resolute, clear-minded, and sharp.

in order to prevent doubt and error, he wrote to the local governor to serve as corroborating evidence.

Cheng crossed the ocean to the country and brought the teachings and Dharma. He pointed to a mountain as Tiantai and called a temple Guoqing. As the wind blows and the lightning shines, this teaching greatly flourished.

How difficult it is for those who do not know from outside to know what is difficult to know!

Shi Dao Yin, whose surname was Wang, was a person from Pengyuan.
He had a lofty bearing and a vast and tranquil nature.
From a young age, he escaped the toils of the dust and vowed to follow the vast and profound [Buddhist path].
Having followed teachers and mentors, he then wished to travel to various places and attained the essential teachings of the mind from the teacher of the Heze school.
When he returned to his hometown, his reputation as a practitioner spread far and wide. Those who admired his teachings were like those who ascended to the market of Huayin.

His nature was unrestrained, compassionate, patient, and harmonious. People had never seen him show anger, so he was called by that name.
He was the light of the country, and when he reached the capital, the nobility and the common people extended invitations to him, rarely seeing him refuse.

In the middle of the Jianzhong era, he crossed the desert and traveled east, stopping when he felt like it, spending his winters and summers there.
